head.title: A Census Misfire: Conjuring Big Brother

hedline.hl1: A Census Misfire: Conjuring Big Brother

abstract.p: Prof David J Jackson letter on May 2 article says image and slogan on billboards being used by Detroit to spur census participation will create suspicion in minds of public already wary of government; drawing

block.p: Re ''All-Out Fight in Detroit to Keep Census Above a Million'' (news article, May 2):

Detroit's mayor, Dennis Archer, asserts convincingly that because of racial and ethnic diversity here, many residents may be suspicious that their census forms will be used against them by the Immigration and Naturalization Service or the F.B.I.
Re ''All-Out Fight in Detroit to Keep Census Above a Million'' (news article, May 2):

Detroit's mayor, Dennis Archer, asserts convincingly that because of racial and ethnic diversity here, many residents may be suspicious that their census forms will be used against them by the Immigration and Naturalization Service or the F.B.I.
One can't help but wonder, then, why the billboards to promote the completion of census forms used a pair of all-seeing eyes and the slogan ''Detroit: All Eyes Are on You!''

This Orwellian imagery could only have the effect of creating suspicion in the minds of a public already wary of the federal government's intentions. No matter how soothing the mayor's assurances may sound, the images and words on these billboards speak louder and more convincingly.
If Detroit ends up the victim of another census undercount, we should take a hard look at the effect of this pernicious advertising.
The writer is an assistant professor of political science at Bowling Green State University in Ohio.
